Matter is neither created nor destroyed. But if you somehow managed to add some mass to a moving object, you’d have to add more energy. Nothing will happen to the kinetic energy if you don’t add any. Energy is neither created nor destroyed. So the velocity would reduce to about 70%. Doubling mass doubles the kinetic energy when velocity remains constant. Consider E=(0.5)(m)(v^2). On the LHS, we have kinetic energy which we want to track. 0.5 is a constant. And you say velocity does not change so yo can assume even v to be a constant. So E=k(m). Which means kinetic energy is directly proportional to mass. So doubling mass will double the kinetic energy.
